canonical_explanation.text: Light travels in straight lines, which is called rectilinear propagation. When light falls on a smooth, polished surface like a mirror, it bounces back — this is called reflection. The laws of reflection state that: (1) the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection, and (2) the incident ray, reflected ray, and normal all lie in the same plane. Regular reflection occurs on smooth surfaces and produces clear images, while diffused reflection occurs on rough surfaces and scatters light in different directions. A plane mirror forms a virtual, erect, laterally inverted image of the same size as the object. Multiple mirrors can produce multiple images. Sunlight (white light) is composed of seven colours (VIBGYOR), and when passed through a prism, it splits into these colours — this is called dispersion. The human eye works like a camera, with parts like cornea, iris, pupil, lens, and retina working together to form images.
rules: Light travels in straight lines (rectilinear propagation).
Law of reflection: angle of incidence = angle of reflection.
Incident ray, reflected ray, and the normal lie in the same plane.
Regular reflection: smooth surfaces; produces clear images.
Diffused (irregular) reflection: rough surfaces; scatters light in many directions.
Plane mirror image: virtual, erect, laterally inverted, same size, same distance behind mirror.
Multiple mirrors: number of images increases as angle between mirrors decreases.
White light = mixture of 7 colours: VIBGYOR.
Dispersion: splitting of white light into its component colours by a prism.
Human eye: cornea, iris, pupil, lens, retina work together to form images.

questions.question_text: The angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection. This is known as the:
questions.explanation_correct: The first law of reflection states that the angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection. This applies to all types of reflecting surfaces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The law of refraction (A) deals with bending of light. Dispersion (C) is about splitting of light. Gravity (D) is unrelated. The equality of angles of incidence and reflection is the law of reflection (B).

questions.question_text: The angle of incidence is the angle between the incident ray and the:
questions.explanation_correct: The angle of incidence is measured between the incoming (incident) ray and the normal — a line perpendicular to the reflecting surface at the point of incidence.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The angle is not measured from the surface (A), reflected ray (B), or horizontal (D). It is measured between the incident ray and the normal (C) — the perpendicular to the surface.

questions.question_text: In the second law of reflection, the incident ray, reflected ray, and the normal:

options.text: Are always perpendicular to each other
Are always parallel to each other

questions.explanation_correct: The second law of reflection states that the incident ray, the reflected ray, and the normal at the point of incidence all lie in the same plane.
questions.explanation_incorrect: They are not perpendicular (A) or parallel (C) to each other. They do not lie in different planes (D). They all lie in the same plane (B) — this is the second law of reflection.

questions.question_text: When a beam of parallel light rays falls on a smooth surface, all rays are reflected in the same direction. This is called:
questions.explanation_correct: When parallel light rays reflect from a smooth, polished surface and all reflect in the same direction, it is called regular reflection. This produces clear images, as in a plane mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diffused reflection (A) scatters light in many directions. Scattering (C) involves light dispersing in all directions. Absorption (D) means light is taken in. Regular reflection (B) occurs on smooth surfaces.

questions.question_text: Diffused reflection occurs when light falls on a:
questions.explanation_correct: Diffused (irregular) reflection occurs when light falls on a rough, uneven surface. Each small part of the surface has a different normal, so the reflected rays scatter in many directions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Smooth mirrors (A) and polished metals (B) produce regular reflection. Transparent glass (D) transmits light. Rough surfaces (C) scatter light in different directions, causing diffused reflection.

questions.question_text: If the angle of incidence is 40°, the angle of reflection will be:
questions.explanation_correct: According to the law of reflection, the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection. If the angle of incidence is 40°, the angle of reflection is also 40°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By the law of reflection, the angle of reflection equals the angle of incidence. It is not 20° (A), 80° (C), or 50° (D). It is 40° (B), the same as the angle of incidence.

questions.question_text: We can see objects that do not produce their own light because they:

options.text: Reflect light that falls on them, and this reflected light enters our eyes
Produce light when we look at them

questions.explanation_correct: We see non-luminous objects because they reflect the light from a source (like the sun or a bulb). This reflected light enters our eyes, and we perceive the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If objects absorbed all light (A), they would appear black. They don't produce light (C). Being transparent (D) would make them hard to see. We see them because they reflect light (B) into our eyes.

questions.question_text: A rough surface reflects light in many different directions. Despite this, the laws of reflection:

options.text: Do not apply to rough surfaces
Apply at each point of the surface individually

questions.explanation_correct: The laws of reflection apply at every point on the rough surface individually. Each small part of the surface has its own normal, and light reflects according to the law at that point. The overall effect is scattered reflection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The laws of reflection are not violated (A), modified (C), or limited to mirrors (D). They apply at each individual point (B) on the rough surface, even though the overall effect is scattering.

questions.question_text: The image formed by a plane mirror is:
questions.explanation_correct: A plane mirror forms an image that is virtual (cannot be caught on a screen), erect (upright), laterally inverted (left and right are swapped), and the same size as the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plane mirror images are not real (A, C) because they form behind the mirror. They are not diminished (D). They are virtual, erect, and laterally inverted (B).

questions.question_text: The image formed by a plane mirror is at the same distance ___ the mirror as the object is in front.
questions.explanation_correct: In a plane mirror, the image is formed behind the mirror at the same distance from the mirror as the object is in front. This makes the image virtual — it cannot be caught on a screen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The image is not in front (A), above (C), or below (D) the mirror. It is behind (B) the mirror, at the same distance as the object is in front.

questions.question_text: The angle of incidence is always equal to the angle of reflection.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The first law of reflection states that the angle of incidence is always equal to the angle of reflection. This applies to all reflecting surfaces — smooth or rough.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is the first law of reflection and it always holds true, for all types of reflecting surfaces.

questions.question_text: Diffused reflection does not follow the laws of reflection.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Diffused reflection follows the laws of reflection at each individual point on the surface. The scattering occurs because the normals at different points on a rough surface point in different directions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diffused reflection does follow the laws of reflection. Each tiny flat region on the rough surface reflects light according to the law, but the different orientations cause the light to scatter.

questions.question_text: The image formed by a plane mirror is laterally inverted.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. A plane mirror produces a laterally inverted image — left appears as right and right appears as left. This is why the word 'AMBULANCE' is written in reverse on the front of ambulances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plane mirror images are indeed laterally inverted. The left side of the object appears as the right side in the image and vice versa.

questions.question_text: The perpendicular drawn to the reflecting surface at the point of incidence is called the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The normal is the perpendicular line drawn to the reflecting surface at the point where the light ray hits. Angles of incidence and reflection are both measured from this normal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'normal'. It is the reference line from which angles of incidence and reflection are measured.

questions.question_text: In a plane mirror, the left side of an object appears as the right side in the image. This is called ___ inversion.
questions.explanation_correct: Lateral inversion is the phenomenon where the left and right sides of an object appear swapped in its mirror image. The word 'AMBULANCE' is written in reverse so it reads correctly in a car's rear-view mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'lateral'. Lateral inversion refers to the left-right reversal seen in plane mirror images.

questions.question_text: The splitting of white light into seven colours by a prism is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Dispersion is the splitting of white light into its seven component colours (VIBGYOR) when it passes through a prism. This happens because different colours travel at different speeds in glass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'dispersion'. A prism disperses white light into violet, indigo, blue, green, yellow, orange, and red.

questions.question_text: If you stand 2 metres in front of a plane mirror, your image will be:

options.text: 2 metres in front of the mirror

questions.explanation_correct: In a plane mirror, the image is formed at the same distance behind the mirror as the object is in front. So if you are 2 metres in front, your image is 2 metres behind the mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The image distance equals the object distance in a plane mirror. 4 metres (B) and 1 metre (C) are wrong distances. The image is behind the mirror, not in front (D). It is 2 metres behind (A).

questions.question_text: The word 'AMBULANCE' is written in reverse on the front of ambulances so that:

options.text: Drivers see it correctly as 'AMBULANCE' in their rear-view mirrors
It identifies the ambulance at night

questions.explanation_correct: The word 'AMBULANCE' is written in reverse so that when drivers ahead see it in their rear-view mirror, the lateral inversion by the mirror makes it read correctly as 'AMBULANCE', allowing them to give way quickly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not for appearance (A), speed (C), or nighttime identification (D). The reversed text reads correctly (B) in rear-view mirrors due to lateral inversion.

questions.question_text: If two plane mirrors are placed facing each other in parallel, the number of images formed is:
questions.explanation_correct: When two plane mirrors are placed parallel to each other and facing each other, they create an infinite number of images. Each mirror reflects the image from the other mirror repeatedly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Parallel mirrors do not form just one (A), two (B), or five (C) images. Light bounces back and forth between the mirrors, creating an infinite (D) number of images that become progressively fainter.

questions.question_text: A kaleidoscope works on the principle of:
questions.explanation_correct: A kaleidoscope uses multiple plane mirrors (usually three) arranged at angles to each other. Light reflects multiple times between these mirrors, creating beautiful symmetrical patterns from small coloured objects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A kaleidoscope does not use refraction (A), dispersion (C), or absorption (D). It works on multiple reflections (B) between mirrors arranged inside a tube.

questions.question_text: If two plane mirrors are placed at 90° to each other, the number of images formed of an object placed between them is:
questions.explanation_correct: When two plane mirrors are at 90°, the number of images = (360°/90°) - 1 = 4 - 1 = 3. Three images are formed by multiple reflections between the two mirrors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The formula for images between two mirrors at angle θ is n = (360/θ) - 1. For 90°: n = 4 - 1 = 3. Not 2 (A), 4 (C), or infinite (D). The answer is 3 (B).

questions.question_text: Sunlight is composed of:

options.text: Seven colours: Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, Red

questions.explanation_correct: Sunlight (white light) is composed of seven colours: Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, and Red (VIBGYOR). This was demonstrated by Newton's prism experiment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sunlight is not just red and blue (A), a single white colour (B), or three colours (D). It is a mixture of seven colours (C) — VIBGYOR.

questions.question_text: When white light passes through a prism, it splits into seven colours. The order of colours from bottom to top of the spectrum is:

options.text: Red, Orange, Yellow, Green, Blue, Indigo, Violet
Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, Red
Red, Blue, Green, Yellow, Violet, Orange, Indigo

questions.explanation_correct: When white light is dispersed by a prism, violet bends the most and appears at the bottom, while red bends the least and appears at the top. The order from bottom to top is VIBGYOR.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A gives the order from top to bottom. Option C has a random order. Option D is incorrect. The correct order from bottom to top is VIBGYOR (B).

questions.question_text: A rainbow is formed because of:

options.text: Dispersion and reflection of sunlight by water droplets

questions.explanation_correct: A rainbow is formed when sunlight enters water droplets in the atmosphere. Inside the droplet, light undergoes dispersion (splitting into colours) and reflection. The dispersed light exits the droplet, creating the rainbow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Only reflection (A) doesn't explain the colours. Clouds don't absorb light to form rainbows (C). Moonlight can form faint rainbows but sunlight is the main cause (D). Rainbows form by dispersion and reflection (B) in water droplets.

questions.question_text: The coloured part of the eye that controls the size of the pupil is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The iris is the coloured, muscular part of the eye that controls the size of the pupil. In bright light, the iris contracts to make the pupil smaller; in dim light, it expands to make the pupil larger.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cornea (A) is the transparent front cover. The retina (B) is the light-sensitive screen at the back. The lens (D) focuses light. The iris (C) is the coloured part that controls pupil size.

questions.question_text: In the human eye, the image is formed on the:
questions.explanation_correct: The retina is the light-sensitive screen at the back of the eye where the image is formed. It contains special cells (rods and cones) that detect light and send signals to the brain via the optic nerve.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cornea (A) refracts light. The iris (B) controls pupil size. The lens (C) focuses light. The image is formed on the retina (D), which sends signals to the brain.

questions.question_text: The opening in the centre of the iris through which light enters the eye is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The pupil is the dark, central opening in the iris. It allows light to enter the eye. Its size is controlled by the iris — small in bright light and large in dim light.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cornea (A) is the transparent front covering. The retina (C) is the screen at the back. The optic nerve (D) carries signals to the brain. The pupil (B) is the opening that lets light in.

questions.question_text: When you enter a dark room from bright sunlight, you cannot see clearly for a short time because:

options.text: Your eyes stop working in the dark
The pupil needs time to dilate (become larger) to let more light in
There is no light in the room

questions.explanation_correct: In bright light, the pupil is small. When you enter a dark room, the pupil needs time to dilate (expand) to allow more light to enter the eye. Until this adjustment happens, vision is temporarily poor.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eyes do work in the dark (A). There is some light in the room (C). While the lens may adjust, the primary reason is the pupil adjusting its size (B). The pupil takes time to dilate.

questions.question_text: A plane mirror always forms an image that is:

options.text: The same size as the object

questions.explanation_correct: A plane mirror always forms an image that is the same size as the object. The image is neither magnified nor diminished — it is an exact copy in terms of size.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plane mirror images are never larger (A), smaller (B), or variable in size (D). They are always the same size (C) as the object.

questions.question_text: Which of the following letters will look the same in a plane mirror?
questions.explanation_correct: The letter 'A' is symmetrical about a vertical axis, so it looks the same when laterally inverted in a plane mirror. Letters like B, P, and R are not vertically symmetrical and will appear reversed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Letters B (A), P (C), and R (D) are not symmetrical about a vertical axis, so they appear reversed in a mirror. The letter A (B) is vertically symmetrical and looks the same.

questions.question_text: If two plane mirrors are placed at 60° to each other, the number of images of an object placed between them is:
questions.explanation_correct: The number of images = (360°/angle) - 1 = (360°/60°) - 1 = 6 - 1 = 5. Five images are formed when mirrors are at 60° to each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using n = (360/θ) - 1: n = (360/60) - 1 = 5. Not 3 (A), 6 (C), or infinite (D). The answer is 5 (B).

questions.question_text: Newton used a second prism to recombine the seven colours back into white light. This proved that:

options.text: The prism adds colours to light
White light is made up of seven colours, and the prism only separates them
Light cannot pass through two prisms

questions.explanation_correct: Newton's experiment with two prisms showed that white light is already composed of seven colours. The first prism separates them, and the second recombines them. The prism does not create colours.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The prism does not add (A) or create (C) colours. Light can pass through two prisms (D). Newton proved that white light is composed of seven colours (B) that the prism merely separates.

questions.question_text: White light is a single colour of light.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. White light is not a single colour but a mixture of seven colours: Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, and Red (VIBGYOR). This is demonstrated by dispersion through a prism.
questions.explanation_incorrect: White light is actually a combination of seven different colours. A prism proves this by dispersing white light into its constituent colours.

questions.question_text: The image formed by a plane mirror can be collected on a screen.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. The image formed by a plane mirror is virtual — it appears to be behind the mirror and cannot be collected or projected on a screen. Only real images can be projected on a screen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plane mirror images are virtual, meaning they form behind the mirror. Virtual images cannot be projected on a screen — only real images can.

questions.question_text: The pupil of the eye becomes smaller in bright light to reduce the amount of light entering the eye.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. In bright light, the iris muscles contract to make the pupil smaller. This reduces the amount of light entering the eye and protects the sensitive retina from damage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The iris adjusts the pupil size — smaller in bright light to limit light entry, and larger in dim light to allow more light in.

questions.question_text: Reflection from a rough surface is called ___ reflection.
questions.explanation_correct: Diffused (or irregular) reflection occurs when light hits a rough surface. The light scatters in many directions because each part of the surface has a different normal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'diffused'. Rough surfaces cause diffused reflection where light is scattered in many different directions.

questions.question_text: The transparent front part of the eye that helps in focusing light is the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The cornea is the transparent, curved front part of the eye. It refracts (bends) incoming light and helps in preliminary focusing before the light reaches the lens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'cornea'. The cornea is the first part of the eye that light passes through, and it does most of the light bending.

questions.question_text: If a ray of light falls perpendicularly (at 0° angle of incidence) on a plane mirror, it will:

options.text: Reflect back along the same path

questions.explanation_correct: When a ray falls perpendicularly on a mirror, the angle of incidence is 0°. By the law of reflection, the angle of reflection is also 0°. The ray reflects back along the same path — it retraces its path.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ray doesn't pass through (A) or get absorbed (D). It doesn't reflect at 90° (C). With 0° angle of incidence, the angle of reflection is also 0°, so the ray reflects back along the same path (B).

questions.question_text: An object moves 5 cm closer to a plane mirror. By how much does the distance between the object and its image change?
questions.explanation_correct: In a plane mirror, the distance between the object and its image equals twice the distance from the object to the mirror. If the object moves 5 cm closer, the image also moves 5 cm closer. So the total distance decreases by 5 + 5 = 10 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The object-image distance = 2 times the object-mirror distance. If object moves 5 cm closer, image moves 5 cm closer to the mirror too. Total change = 5 + 5 = 10 cm (B). Not 5 (A), 2.5 (C), or 0 (D).

questions.question_text: A kaleidoscope typically uses three mirrors arranged to form a:
questions.explanation_correct: A kaleidoscope uses three plane mirrors arranged in a triangular (equilateral triangle) shape inside a tube. The multiple reflections between these three mirrors create beautiful symmetrical patterns.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mirrors are not arranged as a square (A), circle (C), or rectangle (D). Three mirrors are arranged in a triangular (B) formation to create symmetrical patterns through multiple reflections.

questions.question_text: In the visible spectrum (VIBGYOR), which colour bends the most when white light passes through a prism?
questions.explanation_correct: Violet light bends the most when passing through a prism because it has the shortest wavelength and the highest frequency among visible colours. Red light bends the least.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Red (A) bends the least. Yellow (B) and green (D) bend moderately. Violet (C) bends the most because of its shortest wavelength.

questions.question_text: Which colour of light bends the least when passing through a prism?
questions.explanation_correct: Red light bends the least when passing through a prism because it has the longest wavelength and lowest frequency among visible colours. Violet bends the most.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Violet (A) bends the most. Blue (B) and green (C) bend more than red. Red (D) bends the least because of its longest wavelength.

questions.question_text: Which part of the human eye changes shape to focus on objects at different distances?
questions.explanation_correct: The eye lens can change its shape (become thinner or thicker) with the help of ciliary muscles. This ability to adjust focus for different distances is called accommodation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cornea (A) is fixed in shape. The iris (B) controls pupil size. The retina (D) is the screen. The lens (C) changes shape to focus on near and far objects — this is called accommodation.

questions.question_text: The Braille system helps visually impaired people by:

options.text: Using raised dots that can be read by touch

questions.explanation_correct: The Braille system uses patterns of raised dots on paper or other surfaces that visually impaired people can read by running their fingertips over them. Each pattern represents a letter, number, or punctuation mark.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Braille does not magnify images (A), play audio (C), or use lights (D). It uses raised dots (B) that can be felt with fingertips to represent text.

questions.question_text: We can read a book from every direction because the pages produce:
questions.explanation_correct: The pages of a book have a rough surface, so they produce diffused reflection. This scatters light in all directions, allowing the book to be read from any angle or direction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Regular reflection (A) would only send light in one direction. Total internal reflection (C) and refraction (D) are different phenomena. Diffused reflection (B) scatters light in all directions, making the book readable from any angle.

questions.question_text: A periscope uses plane mirrors to:

options.text: Allow viewing objects from behind obstacles using multiple reflections

questions.explanation_correct: A periscope uses two plane mirrors placed at 45° angles to reflect light from above an obstacle down to the viewer's eyes below. It is used in submarines to see above the water surface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A periscope does not magnify (A), split light (C), or create virtual reality (D). It allows viewing over obstacles (B) using two mirrors that redirect light through reflections.

questions.question_text: As the angle between two plane mirrors decreases, the number of images formed increases.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The number of images = (360/angle) - 1. As the angle decreases, the quotient increases, so more images are formed. When mirrors are parallel (angle = 0), infinite images form.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The formula n = (360/θ) - 1 shows that as θ decreases, n increases. Parallel mirrors (θ = 0) give infinite images.

questions.question_text: The seven colours of the visible spectrum are collectively represented by the acronym ___.
questions.explanation_correct: VIBGYOR stands for Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, and Red — the seven colours of the visible spectrum arranged from shortest to longest wavelength.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'VIBGYOR'. This acronym represents the seven colours of the visible spectrum in order: Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, Red.

questions.question_text: The light-sensitive screen at the back of the eye where images are formed is called the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The retina is the light-sensitive layer at the back of the eye. It contains photoreceptor cells (rods and cones) that convert light into electrical signals sent to the brain via the optic nerve.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'retina'. The retina acts as the screen of the eye where images are formed and light signals are converted into nerve impulses.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is good practice for caring for your eyes?

options.text: Washing eyes regularly and eating foods rich in Vitamin A
Rubbing eyes frequently with dirty hands

questions.explanation_correct: Good eye care includes washing eyes with clean water, eating foods rich in Vitamin A (like carrots, green vegetables), reading in adequate light, and getting regular eye check-ups.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reading in dim light (A) strains the eyes. Looking at the sun (B) can cause permanent damage. Rubbing with dirty hands (D) causes infections. Washing eyes and eating Vitamin A-rich foods (C) is proper eye care.
